Graphical abstract This paper reviews the theoretical progress and its applications of porous metal oxides in electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction in recent years, summarizes the challenges and future directions. The global energy-related CO2 emissions have rapidly increased as the world economy heavily relied on fossil fuels. This paper explores the pressing challenge of CO2 emissions and highlights the role of porous metal oxide materials in the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 (CO2RR). The focus is on the development of robust and selective catalysts, particularly metal and metal-oxide-based materials. Porous metal oxides offer high surface area, enhancing the accessibility to active sites and improving reaction kinetics. The tunability of these materials allows for tailored catalytic behavior, targeting optimized reaction mechanisms for CO2RR. The work also discusses the various synthesis strategies and identifies key structural and compositional features, addressing challenges like high overpotential, poor selectivity, and low stability. Based on these insights, we suggest avenues for future research on porous metal oxide materials for electrochemical CO2 reduction. Keywords CO2 reduction Carbon dioxide Transformation Porous metal oxides Electrocatalysis 1 Introduction The extensive use of fossil fuels (such as coal) has accelerated global economic development in recent decades. However, it has also led to vast amounts of CO2 emission. Excessive increases in carbon dioxide emissions could lead to excessive levels of CO2 in the atmosphere. Too much CO2 may contribute to global temperature rise, sea level rise, species extinction, and other environmental disasters [1,2]. Despite efforts to adsorb, capture, and store CO2, atmospheric levels continue to grow daily [3–5], necessitating the search for renewable energy sources to support human development [6–9]. Alternative fuels, such as wind, geothermal, and solar energy, have gradually matured but still face challenges due to uncertainties such as location, environment, and efficiency [10]. As a stable, cheap, and abundant resource, CO2 could be converted into C1 products like methanol and formic acid [11], as well as C≥2 products like CO, ethylene, and ethanol [12]. Currently, four methods, electrochemical [13,14], photochemical [15–17], thermochemical [12,18,19], and biochemical [20,21], are favored for CO2 utilization. These methods have distinct strengths, and when combined or overlapped, they could result in higher treatment efficiency [22–24] (Fig. 1 ). A main challenge in CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) is the development of selective and robust catalysts. Metal and metal-oxide-based catalysts have drawn significant attention in this area [25]. Specifically, metal oxide catalysts are sought to reduce CO2 at low overpotentials, producing desirable products without unwanted byproducts [25–28]. Metal oxides offer tunable electronic and structural properties, allowing for tailored catalytic behavior. Advanced synthesis techniques, such as sol–gel, hydrothermal, and atomic layer deposition, are employed to fabricate catalysts with controlled size, shape, and surface properties [29]. Metal oxides are often synthesized as nano-structures, which provides increased surface area and exposes more active sites, thereby enhancing catalytic activity [30]. The integration of metal oxide into functional devices, such as electrolyzers, is also under exploration, facing challenges in scalability, durability, and economic feasibility. Computational studies could aid this process by providing deeper insights into reaction mechanisms. Tools like density functional theory (DFT) model interactions between CO2 and metal oxide surfaces, offer a better understanding of what governs catalytic behavior [27]. However, one major drawback of most metal oxides is their poor electrical conductivity, limiting their efficiency as CO2 electrocatalysts. Common bulk metal oxides are usually limited by low electrochemically active surface areas (ECSA) and limited mass transfer [31]. Several innovations are summarized for metal oxides used for CO2RR. These include a variety of catalyst morphologies (such as nanosheets, nanowires and nanoparticles), which have been found to promote charge transfer and reduce CO2RR overpotentials [28,30,32]. Among them, porous metal oxides have received attention for their better lifetime and mass transfer. They offer high specific surface areas, improving electron mobility and mass transfer [33–35]. The porous structure increases the number of active sites available for reactant adsorption, thereby enhancing overall reaction rates [30]. Moreover, researchers could adjust pore sizes, shapes, and structures, gaining unprecedented control over their catalytic properties [29]. For the CO2RR, nanoconfinement effect is also crucial to enhance selectivity and efficiency. The confinement effects create localized environments that promote specific reaction pathways. For instance, the effect could help stabilize certain intermediates or offer a geometric arrangement favorable for reaction steps [36]. This paper summarizes systematic insights into the behavior and evolution of porous metal oxides in electrochemical reduction of CO2. The discussion also includes the intricate relationships among various factors, such as material composition, phase transitions, and structural changes during the reaction. By utilizing these insights, researchers could examine the characteristics, impact, and potential of porous metal oxides in developing future electrochemical CO2RR technologies. 2 Mechanism of CO2 electrocatalytic reduction on porous metal oxide materials 2.1 Explanation of the mechanism of electrochemical reduction of CO2 The electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 has attracted the attention of researchers with milder reaction conditions and better controllability. The CO2 molecule is known to be extremely stable due to its CO double bond, which has a high bond energy compared to CC, CO, and CH single bonds [37]. This high dissociation energy necessitates more activation energy for the direct dissociation of the CO bond, resulting in significant energy consumption. Consequently, a catalyst is required to provide a catalytic center to improve charge transfer efficiency and achieve the conversion of CO2 [38]. In general, the process of electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 will include: (1) activation of CO2, (2) reaction of CO2 on the catalyst, and (3) desorption of the products. In detail, it could be divided into: (1) dissolution of CO2 in the electrolyte, (2) transfer of CO2 from the electrolyte to the interface with the catalyst, (3) adsorption of CO2 on the catalyst surface, (4) conversion of CO2 to reaction intermediates, (5) electron transfer and proton-electron coupling, (6) desorption of reaction products, and (7) products entering the gas or liquid phase and being collected [39]. In this case, since the dissociation energy of CO in the CO2 molecule is 750 kJ mol−1, CO2 requires a very negative redox potential to be converted to *CO2 radicals as Eq. (1) [40]. (1) ∗ + C O 2 + e - → ∗ C O 2 - Therefore, to some extent, this takes up more of the energy demand in the overall CO2 electrocatalytic reduction process. Many different kinds of products are produced during the reaction. Usually, there are several electron transfer steps in the reaction. There will be an odd number of electron transfers in the CO2 activation step, as shown in Eq. (1) [40]. The formation of partial reaction intermediates will also undergo an odd number of electron changes, as shown in Eq. (2) [41]. However, from the perspective of the overall reaction process, an even number of electrons are transferred in the process of converting CO2 into products (such as CO). This is determined by the O lost and the H proton gained of CO2 [42–44]. (2) C O 2 + e - + H + → H O C O - Therefore, the mechanism of CO2 electrocatalytic reduction could be more complicated. The cathodic reactions involved are shown in Table 1 [45,46]. During the activation of CO2, the CO bond will be weakened, and CO2 will form a chemical bond with the active site on the catalyst surface. It is intended to stabilize *CO2 − radicals and intermediates [47]. In the next step, different reactions lead to different products [48] (Fig. 2 a). Regarding electron transfer numbers, CO and HCOOH are produced through a 2-electron transfer process but do not use the same reaction pathway. For example, the adsorption of C atoms with the catalyst will tend to produce the intermediate *COOH. This intermediate is formed through protonation adsorbs by cleaving the CO bond to produce *CO, which further produces CO [49]. However, the mechanism of the generation of *COOH intermediates is still controversial at present. One idea is that the *CO2 − formed by electron transfer will be hydrogenated to form *COOH. The other is *COOH formed in one step by proton coupled electron transfer (PCET) [50]. The intermediate *OCHO is generally considered to be the key to the process of forming HCOOH and HCOO−. In particular, this intermediate does not break the CO bond during formation, but adsorption occurs between the O atom and the catalyst [51]. Some researchers have shown that the formation of *OCHO originates from a bicarbonate intermediate. CO2 will react with *OH adsorbed on the catalyst surface to form the intermediate [52,53]. Moreover, the hydrogen or hydroxyl groups adsorbed on the catalyst surface will also contribute to the formation of HCOOH [54]. In further profound reduction, the hydrogenation reaction generates *CO to *CHO, which in turn generates CH4. Although CH4 is not a C≥2 product, it is required to undergo an 8-electron transfer in the reaction [55]. Furthermore, if the adsorption stability is strong, the C1 intermediate will undergo a CC coupling reaction. This dimerization reaction leads to the formation of *COCHO intermediate from two *CO. After multiple protons and electrons have involved in the reaction, C≥2 products C2H4 and C2H5OH could be produced [56]. Further, C2H4 could continue to react with *CO to form products such as C3H7OH. Among various catalysts, researchers have favored copper catalysts [57] (Fig. 2b). 2.2 Some technical difficulties with mechanism of CO2 electrocatalytic reduction There are still some technical difficulties in the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2. The problems are mainly focused on (1) low CO2 conversion efficiency of electrode materials and low selectivity of target products, (2) competing reactions due to the negative potential of the cathode, (3) waste of feedstock or energy due to low per-pass conversion efficiency, (4) low stability of electrode material. For the first problem, researchers now have ideas to solve it. For example, oxide composites could form composite surface active sites, which improve electrocatalytic activity. At the same time, active sites could be increased by adjusting the catalyst crystallinity and creating structural defects [59–61]. Introducing porous structures could improve the specific surface area, facilitate electrolyte transport and accelerate mass transport on the nano-sized electrocatalyst's surface area [62]. For the second problem, the most common competing reaction is hydrogenolysis reaction (HER) [63]. To inhibit HER and promote CC coupling to C≥2 products, most studies are performed in neutral or alkaline electrolytes. A strongly alkaline microenvironment is usually generated at the cathodic interface due to high current densities [44]. However, firstly this may lead to the depletion of a major part of the CO2 feed. CO3 2− or HCO3 − are produced by the reaction between CO2 and OH−. They cross the anion exchange membrane (AEM) to the anode and react with H+ from the oxygen precipitation reaction (OER). They react to produce CO2 and eject [64]. This reduces the theoretical per-pass conversion of CO2 and leads to underutilization of the feedstock [65–67]. The important role of balancing the rate of carbonate or bicarbonate formation and proton diffusion in determining selectivity and activity has been emphasized. This clarifies the mechanistic pathways controlling carbon loss [46,68]. At present, the stability of the gas diffusion electrode (GDE), especially the gas diffusion layer (GDL), is also facing problems: carbonation and flooding [43]. The carbonation comes from the plugging of carbonate in CO2RR. The development of specialized coatings and treatments are used to enhance the stability of GDL [69]. An innovative solution is conducting the reaction in acids (Fig. 3 a and b). Flooding leads to severe HER in an aqueous medium. It caused by carbonation or the penetration of aqueous electrolyte into the GDE [69]. Innovations in GDL design, such as optimizing porosity and surface characteristics, have been instrumental in improving gas distribution and minimizing the risk of flooding [70]. Furthermore, real-time monitoring and analysis of GDL properties have provided valuable insights into their dynamic behavior during operation [71]. At present, there is some controversy about the C source of the products in CO2RR. Some researchers have considered the possibility that solvents may become feedstock for CO2RR. For example, Girardi et al. found that a small amount of formaldehyde was produced in the solvent CH2Cl2 without CO2. However, the production considerably increased when CO2 replaced the air in the reaction, suggesting that the main C source of formaldehyde in electrolysis is still CO2 [72]. In contrast, Altaf et al. performed tests in 0.1 M KHCO3 solution with Ar. There was no CO2RR product produced. The results indicate that the carbon-containing products in CO2RR are not from other carbon compounds in the electrolyte or catalyst [73]. However, the issue remains controversial at present. Some researchers have also hypothesized a fast equilibrium between CO2 and bicarbonate. They found that the source of CO2 in the reaction was not free CO2 supplied directly to the solution but CO2 in equilibrium with the bicarbonate anion [74,75]. Currently, the theoretical calculation method by computer model construction and simulation is becoming increasingly popular. The Computational Hydrogen Electrode (CHE) model is a key computational tool for studying CO2 electrocatalytic reduction. With the Density Functional Theory (DFT), it provides a simplified yet detailed view of the electrochemical interface, focusing on crucial steps like reactant adsorption, intermediate formation, and product desorption [76,77]. This method provides valuable details often hard to characterize from experiments alone. The CHE model has been particularly effective in screening electrocatalysts for CO2 reduction, such as copper (Cu) [78]. However, the model has limitations. It does not distinguish between complex proton-transfer steps, which is a significant drawback if proton coupling is a key element of the reaction [79,80]. It also assumes zero charge on the catalyst surface before the reaction starts, overlooking the influence of electrostatic interactions. Due to these limitations, there is a strong case for integrating the CHE model with experimental research. This hybrid approach could provide a more complete understanding of electrode reaction mechanisms and offer new, efficient pathways for CO2 reduction [63,81,82]. 3 Application of different materials 3.1 Metal oxides and their composites The metal oxide or composite metal oxide materials with special structures are known for their unique structures and versatile properties. Researchers often combine materials to concentrate characteristics and modify surfaces to introduce more active sites [83,84]. Preparation methods dictate the resulting structures, such as porous or multilayer structures, which benefit CO2 catalytic reduction. These structures enhance electron mobility, making them practical for catalysis, sensing, and energy conversion and storage. In recent years, porous metal oxide materials have garnered attention due to their electrocatalytic processes, which expand reactant molecules and improve electron mobility in the solid pathway through porous metal networks. Optimizing these aspects could contribute to developing more efficient and sustainable CO2 conversion technologies [83,85,86] (Table 2 ). 3.1.1 Material structure Composite metal oxide catalysts' highly porous structures, particularly their mesoporous structures, offer significant advantages for CO2RR by increasing the specific surface area, promoting charge movement, rapid mass transfer, and enhanced electron mobility. Chen et al. used hexagonal phase In2O3 as a CO2RR catalyst with a monodisperse porous nanosphere structure [64]. The h-In2O3 could effectively reduce CO2 to formate with an FE of 98%. This efficiency significantly outperformed its cubic phase counterpart, highlighting the importance of porous structure in enhancing catalytic effects and promoting CO2RR [97,105]. After electrolysis, the researchers examined the h-In2O3 catalyst by XRD, and the characteristic peaks showed that the sample maintained a hexagonal phase (Fig. 4 a). After 5 h of electrolysis, the device could obtain 0.05 mol of potassium formate with a total conversion efficiency of 89.2%. After Raman spectroscopy detection, h-In2O3 did not show the CO3 2− peak for 50 min, indicating that carbonate formation was relatively slow (Fig. 4b). Liu et al. prepared nanoporous Sn/SnO2 (np-Sn/SnO2) with a mesoporous structure [87]. The catalyst had greater than an FEHCOOH of 70% over a wide potential range of −0.8 to −1.4 V (vs. RHE). The large ECSA provided by this three-dimensional porous structure could endow the material with many active sites and allow for faster mass transport. It could be stabilized for 58 h at −0.8 V, and the morphology of the np-Sn/SnO2 composite was essentially the same as that before use. Meanwhile, the authors performed XPS analysis on the np-Sn/SnO2 composites after utilization. The percentage of Sn0 increased from 21.8% to 30%. This may be due to the reduction of Sn4+ to Sn0 during CO2RR electrolysis. Similarly, Wu et al. prepared sheet-like heterophase SnO2/Sn3O4 using a facile hydrothermal process [106] (Fig. 4c). This catalyst exhibits a uniform sheet structure (Fig. 4d). The FEHCOOH of this catalyst was 88.3% at −0.9 V (vs. RHE). After successive CO2RRs, Sn appeared in SnO2/Sn3O4. They were mainly converted from SnO2, and most Sn3O4 remained in the catalyst. This indicates that the active catalyst in the reaction is Sn/SnO x . The O-SnIV content in SnO2, SnO2/Sn3O4 is significantly decreased relative to O-SnII, indicating that SnO2 is readily reduced to the lower valent state Sn in the catalysts. Further evidence from SEM images showed that almost all SnO2 nanoflowers lost their original morphology after the electrocatalytic reaction, except for Sn3O4 and SnO2/Sn3O4, which showed no significant change in morphology. There are many holes of different sizes in the heterogeneous SnO2/Sn3O4. Their formation is mainly attributed to the reduction or dissolution of SnO2 under negative potentials (Fig. 4e and f). This porous structure facilitates CO2RR on SnO2/Sn3O4. Yang et al. developed Cu2O catalysts with nanocavities [103]. Cu+ is considered to have the potential to catalyze C≥2 products. They are reduced to Cu0 at cathodic potentials where C≥2 could be formed. Some carbon intermediates will cover the localized catalyst surface. The catalyst could limit their in-situ formation, thus stabilizing the Cu+ species (Fig. 5 a). When the partial current density of C≥2 was 267 ± 13 mA cm−2, FEC≥2 could reach 75.2%±2.7%. Raman spectroscopy demonstrated that the porous Cu2O retained characteristic Raman modes after 20 min of electrocatalysis (Fig. 5b). The authors concluded that *CO intermediates are confined to the porous structure when Cu+ is protected from reduction. This also facilitates subsequent CC coupling, resulting in high selectivity for C≥2 products. Single-cavity structures have been observed to concentrate carbon intermediates through spatial confinement effects. The authors also followed the evolution of the Cu K-edge XAS spectra as a function of reaction time (Fig. 5c). In agreement with Raman measurements, after 20 min of reaction in a flow cell, the authors calculated Cu+ species in porous Cu2O up to 32.1%. The authors also used finite element simulations to explore whether the multi-chambered particulate catalyst could confine these intermediates. The simulation results show that CO2 molecules will undergo the following steps: (1) diffusion to the catalyst surface (Fig. 6 a); (2) adsorption and reduction to C1 species (Fig. 6b); and (3) the possibility of CC coupling of C2 and even C3 products increases as C1 species reach a certain number (Fig. 6c and d). Pores with different radii could all concentrate carbon species. This promotes the formation of C≥2 and also protects the active Cu+ site from reduction. Ge et al. developed a mesoporous C-SnO2 electrocatalyst that could reach a current density of 5 mA cm−2 at −0.8 V (vs. RHE), at which time the peak FECO + FEHCOOH is about 80% [96]. With a pore size of 8 nm, it has excellent CO2 adsorption properties due to its uniform and highly ordered pore distribution. This structure increased the residence time of CO2 within the pores, facilitating the initial electron movement between CO2 and its intermediates CO2*. The C-SnO2 catalyst was agglomerated after the reaction. This suggests that the mesoporous structure of tin oxide was disrupted after prolonged electrochemical testing. This could result in lower CO2 adsorption. Similar theories of holes have also been explored by researchers. Jiang et al. synthesized nanoporous ZnO by hydrothermal method, achieving a maximum FECO of 92.0% at −1.66 V (vs. Ag/AgCl) [98]. The reduced nanoporous ZnO surface had many defects, facilitating the catalytic conversion of physisorbed CO2 molecules to chemisorbed forms of intermediates [107]. The lower Tafel slope of ZnO relative to Zn foil suggests that reduced nanoporous ZnO is susceptible to CO2 electroreduction. Hu et al. synthesized a spherical-ordered macroporous CuO (SOMa-CuO) nanocatalyst with a mesoporous structure using an SBA-15 template [104]. It has a high current density of 52 mA cm−2 at −0.9 V. The catalyst's macroporous system enabled efficient diffusion of CO2 into the network and facilitated quick electron transfer in the nanocatalyst. The spherical catalyst structures interlocked to form a cage-like structure. This could expose more active sites, increase the chances of CO2 interacting with them, and catalyze the reaction. In addition to the material's porous structure, multilayer structures have also emerged as a promising approach to enhance the efficiency of CO2 electrocatalytic reduction. It could provide additional surface area and adsorption sites for reactant molecules. This structure complements the porous structure of the material. Li et al. created a SnO2/CC (carbon cloth) material with a 3D layered structure that functioned as an electrode [93] (Fig. 7 a). This material has exceptional characteristics and a strong, highly porous layered structure that provides a large surface area for the CO2RR (Fig. 7b and c). A massive proportion of 5 nm mesopores are observed in the SnO2 nanosheet layer of SnO2/CC. This endows the material with fast mass transport and electron transfer rates (Fig. 7d). A Tafel slope of 79 mV dec−1 has obtained on SnO2/CC, which is close to the theoretical value for a fast single-electron transfer step (Fig. 7e). Thus CO2 *− formation is not a rate-limiting process but rather is limited by Eq. (3). (3) C O 2 Â · - a d s + H C O 3 - → H C O O - a d s + C O 3 2 - When the overpotential reached 0.88 V, SnO2 /CC could achieve an excellent local current density. The FE of formic acid reaches 87%±2%. These results are even better than those obtained with some gas diffusion electrodes. The mesoporous structure of the material wad well preserved after long-term electrolysis (Fig. 7f). In the XRD spectra of the samples, new peaks attribute to the metal Sn appeared, indicating that the active catalyst in the reaction is Sn or Sn/SnO x (Fig. 7g). In principle, all tin oxide in experiments should be reduced to metallic tin. However, some SnO x existed in a metastable state in a broad potential region far more negative than the normal potential. Therefore, the researchers expected that the composition of Sn/SnO x would not change significantly over the range of potentials used. In addition, the layered structure might enhance the intrinsic properties of porous metal oxide catalysts. H-Sn3O4 nanosheet (H-Sn3O4 NS) prepared by Liu et al. also had a 3D hierarchical structure [90]. This gives the material a large electrochemically active surface area, which promotes charge transfer. The current density of the formate fraction was 421 mA cm−2 at −1.02 V (vs. RHE) when the FEHCOOH was 91.1%. By analyzing the material after the reaction, the researchers found that the morphology, crystal structure, and composition of the H-Sn3O4 NS catalyst were almost unchanged. Zhao et al. demonstrated that a multi-layer structure could inhibit the attenuation of the oxide layer, improving the life and recyclability of the material [108]. 3.1.2 Internal characteristics Due to the characteristics of metal oxides, some materials will expose more grain boundaries. It is believed that these grain boundaries (GBs) could help transform CO2 into valuable products. The local spatial symmetry gives them the ability to adjust the binding energy of reaction intermediates, making them facilitators for CO2 reactions [109,110]. Liu et al. prepared a nanoporous Sn/SnO2 (np-Sn/SnO2) material exhibiting a high-density grain boundary. As shown by HRTEM tests, it revealed clearly defined lattice fringes [87] (Fig. 8 a). The material's porous structure, combined with its high-density grain boundary, promotes excellent CO2 reduction performance. Similarly, Kumar et al. prepared SnO2 porous nanowires (Sn-pNWs) that reduced CO2 to formic acid at a low overpotential, achieving a stable Faradaic efficiency of 80% at −0.8 V (vs. RHE) [92]. This improved performance compared to commercial SnO2 nanoparticles was attributed to the high grain boundary density within the porous structure. However, Sn-pNWs did not have a larger surface area than commercial SnO2 nanoparticles. This means the increased density of active sites. Hu et al. proposed a partially reduced Sn/SnO2 porous hollow fiber (PHF) with improved CO2 adsorption, prepared using electrostatic spinning and reduction processes [91] (Fig. 8c). The FE of formate reached up to 82.1% in a 4-h test at −1.60 V (vs. SCE) (Fig. 8b). After 10 h of continuous CO2 electroreduction, the Sn/SnO2 PHF catalysts showed no significant decay in current density. The porous hollow fibers consisted of approximately 12 nm porous nanoparticles smaller than general SnO2. They exposed more grain boundaries in the cross-section. This could increase the ECSA and promote electrochemical activity [111]. They also found that the Sn/SnO2 PHF catalyst has two specific peaks: 529.8 eV for lattice oxygen and 531.5 eV for oxygen vacancies. After reduction at 500 °C, additional oxygen vacancies were created in the catalyst. Moreover, it has been demonstrated in previous experiments that the total adsorption capacity of carbonate intermediates at high temperatures increases with the concentration of oxygen vacancies in the electrode material. This means the oxygen vacancy sites are the primary locations where CO2 could be adsorbed [112,113]. Therefore, doped oxides with high oxygen vacancy sites and high electron concentrations are particularly suitable for CO2RR [114,115]. Liu et al. hypothesized that SnO2 could effectively achieve CO2RR due to oxygen vacancy because of the material's advantages of electron and atomic structure [88] (Fig. 9 a). A maximum FEHCOOH of 92.4% was achieved with a low overpotential of 0.51 V at −0.7 V (vs. RHE) for VO-SnO2 that they prepared. The current density and FEHCOOH at this potential were unchanged for at least 10 h, indicating excellent stability. The porous structure and chemical composition were also well maintained. The researchers characterized the VO-SnO2 material. The band structure suggested that SnO2 with oxygen vacancies will have smaller band gaps, creating more charge carriers (Fig. 9b). This means that materials will have faster charge transport. While oxygen vacancies give materials more active sites, the intermediates formed on the surface are easier to stabilize [116–118]. To emphasize the value of oxygen vacancies in the CO2RR catalytic process, Rahman et al. prepared a reduction catalyst with mesoporous SnO2 to produce formic acid by a simple nano-casting method [94]. This catalyst achieved an FE of 75% for formic acid at a potential of −1.15 V (vs. RHE) with the current density of 10.8 mA cm−2. The material could continuously electrolyze CO2 for 16 h at −1.15 V, which indicates that m-SnO2 exhibits significant stability to CO2RR. The O 1s spectrum of the material element scanning spectrum observed the fitting peak of the oxygen-containing substance at 532.6 eV. This corresponded to the oxygen vacancy in the synthesis of m-SnO2 (Fig. 9c). It has been shown that mesoporous structures generally have more oxygen vacancies [119]. These vacancies reduce the overpotential generated by formate, enhance CO2 adsorption and make the formate anion radicals generated during CO2RR more stable [120]. 3.1.3 Co-action of materials The interaction between different elements causes the synergistic effect in metal oxide catalysts. It has attracted significant interest due to its potential to enhance the CO2RR process. This positive effect could promote reaction simplicity and combine the advantages of various materials, thus improving the overall catalytic performance. Cu/Ni oxide composites (CuNiOCs) prepared by Yang et al. could produce HCOO− in KHCO3 aqueous electrolyte [31]. The catalyst could achieve a current density of 10.9 mA cm−2 and a FE of 95.9% for HCOO− at a low overpotential of −0.37 V (vs. RHE). During 25 h of use, the catalyst has no significant change in current density and FEHCOO−. Its excellent electrocatalytic performance mainly originated from its porous structure, the synergistic effect of Cu and Ni oxides, the large electrochemical specific surface area, and the low charge transfer resistance. Tan et al. demonstrated that SnO2/ZnO has a synergistic effect [89]. They prepared SnO2/ZnO composites possessing grainy hollow nanofiber (HNF) structures. The FEHCOOH of this material was as high as 97.9% at −1.34 V (vs. RHE). The Tafel slope of the composite SnO2/ZnO HNF is smaller and closer to the theoretical value (118 mV dec−1) than that of SnO2 HNF and NPs. This indicates that the rate-determining step is the initial one-electron transfer step. The higher Tafel slope of the SnO2 HNF and NPs catalysts implies that the rate-determining step on the pure SnO2 surface differs from the generally accepted single electron transfer step. This indirectly suggests that the synergistic interaction between SnO2 and ZnO influences the CO2RR process. Wang et al. prepared Zn2SnO4/SnO2, a highly porous microcube with exposed discordant sites [95]. This structure enhanced the adsorption of CO2. The maximum FE of HCOOH on the catalyst at −1.08 V was about 77%. After testing, the researchers found that the electronic properties of Zn2+ and Sn4+ of Zn2SnO4/SnO2 are essentially the same as before the reaction. This indicates that the surface oxide species of the catalyst is stable. In addition, Zn2SnO4 and SnO2 interacted with the intermediate HCOO* to enhance the selectivity of HCOOH. In addition to Zn, Shi et al. further investigated this synergistic effect by introducing SnO2 and CuO into the alloy [121]. SnO2 enhanced CO2 adsorption and activation, while CuO promoted H2O decomposition and provided more H* intermediates. This combination of metal oxides effectively promoted the CO2RR process. Similarly, the catalyst A-Cu/SnO2 prepared by Li et al. using copper foam modification also has a large specific surface area for catalytic reaction [97]. Cu and Sn exhibit synergistic effects during CO2RR catalysis. The difference in the content of Cu atoms may affect the density of the Cu-Sn interface on the SnO2 surface, which in turn affects the synergistic effect. The total current density was kept at −8.5 mA cm−2 during the experiment. The selectivity of CO was stabilized at about 75% during the 10-h electrolysis. The surface morphology and composition of the catalyst were well maintained. Yang et al. prepared np-Cu@VO2 catalyst [102]. This hierarchical nanoporous copper integrated with VO2 could achieve a Faradaic efficiency of 30.1% for ethanol at −0.62 V (vs. RHE). The hierarchical nanoporous copper skeleton promoted electron and electrolyte transport, and the larger area facilitated the formation of a high active site density. The presence of vanadium oxides on the Cu surface promotes water dissociation. At this time, the adsorption energy of hydrogen on Cu will be optimized, and the energy barriers for CO2 protonation and CC coupling will be reduced. At the same time, it could increase the H+ coverage on the catalyst surface. This inhibits dehydration and favors breaking the CC bond of the *HCCOH intermediate. Li et al. suggested that ZrO2 could stabilize Cu species and maintain their original form for extended periods [101]. The FEC2H4 of this catalyst could reach 54.7%±1.1%. At a current density of 250 mA cm−2, the FEtotal could exceed 84.0%. The increase in ZrO2 content leads to a decrease in FECO, while both total FE and FEC2H4 increase and have peaks with the increase in Zr/Cu molar ratio. The Cu+ species on the CuO@ZrO2 surface remained well after electrolysis at a potential of −1.1 V, probably due to the strong interaction between ZrO2 and CuO (Fig. 10 a). CuO@ZrO2 retained the characteristic Raman peak of Cu2O within 60 min of CO2 electrolysis, which implies that ZrO2 could protect Cu+ species (Fig. 10b). For ordinary CuO catalysts, the Raman signals of CuO and Cu2O disappeared rapidly after 10 min, indicating the complete reduction of Cu2+ to Cu0. Although not having a porous structure, the derivatized hybrid catalysts of In(OH)3-coupled Cu2O prepared by Li et al. [122] and Cu2O/ZnO gas diffusion electrodes prepared by Albo et al. [123] also support this view. In addition to directly facilitating reactions through synergistic interactions, combinations between metals, metal oxides, or non-metallic elements could confer additional advantages on catalysts. Guzmán et al. combined Cu, Zn, and Al oxides to obtain a unique porous metal oxide material with an optimal cone structure [99]. The results show that the catalyst has a high catalytic activity for H2 and CO, with a Faradaic efficiency of 95% for syngas at −0.89 V (vs. RHE). It is mentioned in the paper that Cu2O species have higher stability under electrochemical reduction conditions. This is because the dispersed ZnO and Al2O3 structures stabilize the Cu2O species, and prevents its complete reduction to Cu0 (Fig. 10c–e). Relative to the unused sample, the (111) facet of CuO disappears and the diffraction peak of Cu2O appears in tests performed at −12 mA cm−2 (Fig. 10f–h). A more negative current density (−24 mA cm−2) led to the disappearance of the (11–1) and (202) facets of CuO. Chen et al. suggested that Lewis acid sites in metal oxides (e.g., Al2O3, Cr2O3) could modulate the electronic structure of Cu atoms by optimizing intermediate absorption [100]. They tested the performance of an ultrathin p-Al2O3-supported Cu catalyst at a potential of −1.2 V (vs. RHE). FECH4 approached 62% at this point, and the current density reached 153.0 mA cm−2. Ko et al. have shown that doping F elements in SnO2 could effectively strengthen the interaction of the reaction intermediates with the catalyst surface [124]. When the current density is maintained at 100 mA cm−2, the material could be stabilized for 7 days. The FEHCOOH of the catalyst could be maintained at 90%. Jhong et al. demonstrated this with N-doped indium oxide (ITO) nanocrystals. When ITO nanocrystals were used for CO2 electrolysis under alkaline conditions, the overall change in the catalyst was minimal [125]. They attributed this stability to the presence of oleic acid ligands on the surface of the ITO nanocrystals, which helped stabilize the material in the low-polarity solvent. In this chapter, we summarize the application of metal oxides and their composites possessing porous structures for the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2. As mentioned above, porous metal oxides possess a pore structure that could provide a large specific surface area and ECSA, and they are also helpful for electron transfer and mass transfer. The nano-restricted domain effect possessed by the pores could effectively enrich the reactants and reaction intermediates for faster reduction. Even for the same feedstock, different doping elements significantly impact the performance and structure of the catalyst formed. Meanwhile, some of these substances will undergo valence changes during the use of catalysts due to the reaction. Although these changes are not always harmful, researchers still prefer to pursue more stable material structures and properties for the sake of the catalyst's lifetime. Under ideal reaction conditions, surface modification could improve the stability and activity of the catalyst. In addition, the preparation of catalyst electrodes with multilayer structures facilitates improved stability. Preparation conditions, such as temperature, pressure, pH, and mixing strategy, also considerably affect the formation of the desired catalyst structure and properties. By carefully controlling these parameters, researchers could optimize the catalyst's performance in a given reaction. 3.2 Polyoxometalates Polyoxometalates (POMs) are metal oxide polyanion clusters with complex and diverse structures. The metal ions used in POMs could be derived from Mo, V, Nb, W, and other elements [126]. Because of the shared oxygen atom linkage, POMs form a functional cluster framework with variable and unique excellent properties in redox. POMs consist of multiple connections between cluster chains. This three-dimensional base structure has similarities with the pore structure in porous materials. Therefore, for the synthesis and use of porous metal oxide catalysts, the particular structure and properties of POMs are also very informative [127]. They could perform multiple electron transfer reactions while maintaining their original structure, a characteristic that makes them particularly suitable for CO2RR. Moreover, the backbone of POMs is rich in negative charges, allowing them to easily undergo electrophilic carbon binding when they come into contact with CO2 molecules. These properties make POMs well-suited for CO2RR, as they could act as multi-electron donors [128–131]. Hence, it could be widely used in electrocatalysis, photocatalysis, and energy-related fields [132–136]. Currently, there has been some research in this direction (Table 3 ). 3.2.1 Electron transport optimization Electron transfer efficiency is critical in enhancing CO2RR performance, as efficient electron transfer is vital for achieving high selectivity and low overpotential. One solution for improving electron transfer efficiency is to choose materials with faster electron transfer capabilities. For example, materials with electronic channels could prevent additional energy consumption during the reaction process. When the catalyst has electrons to release, they could replace the original electrons and facilitate rapid transport. This could significantly increase the overall electron transfer efficiency of the CO2RR process. Composite materials and materials that could readily release electrons could further enhance the electron transfer process. Wang et al. prepared {PMoV 8MoVI 4O35(OH)5Zn4} clusters with metalloporphyrin as catalysts [137]. After comparing these clusters with similar materials, they demonstrated that POMs play a crucial role in the CO2RR process [143]. POMs are bound to metalloporphyrins. This results in a backbone well-suited to receiving and supplying electrons in CO2RR. In another study, Zhao et al. comprehensively screened a series of metals anchored to Na4SiMo12 by DFT calculations [63]. They used this model to find that TM@Na4SiMo12 (TM = Sc, Cr, Mn, Ti, and V) has excellent catalytic activity and stability for CO2RR. And they demonstrate that the polymetallic oxygenates act as the accepting and providing electrons in the CO2RR process. In this process, CO2 gains electrons by adsorption on the catalyst. Calculations show that the catalysts lose the same amount of charge simultaneously. Zang et al. further explored the potential of POMs in CO2RR by examining the role of a particular interface formed by the metal and O atoms [141]. The CuOMo interface is the active site for the catalyst Mo8@Cu/TNA, which uses TiO2 nanotubular arrays (TNA) as the carrier. Mo8@Cu/TNA has a higher reduction product diversity and FE than Ag/TNA, which could reach an overall FE of 48.68%. Moreover, the product selectivity could be up to 46.59%. The Cu surface of Mo8@Cu/TNA is modified with Mo oxide clusters. POMs have another thing in common: they positively affect electron transfer efficiency. Wang et al. constructed several metallic 2D polymetallic oxalate-metal porphyrin organic skeletons (TM-PMOFs) by incorporating the reductive Lindqvist-type cluster [Mo6]2e/2H [144]. They calculated that the 2D Co-PMOF only has to surpass a 0.31 eV free energy barrier, which indicates a facilitative effect for the CO2RR reaction. The easiness of gaining versus losing electrons also promotes the relatively transfer of the received electrons from the [Mo6]2e/2H cluster to the central Co atom of the porphyrin ring. Similarly, for the improvement of electron transfer efficiency, similar mixed-valence POM@MOF composites were produced by Sun et al. [129] (Fig. 11 a). POM@PCN-222(Co) composites showed greatly advanced electron transfer properties. Powder X-ray diffractometer (PXRD) spectra and catalyst morphology did not change before and after the electrocatalytic reaction at −0.8 V after 10 h of continuous operation (Fig. 11b). The authors concluded that the polyformaldehyde within the material's pores could shorten the electron transport distance (Fig. 11c). It is shown that new electron channels are established between the POMs and the monometallic dotted Co, which increases the electron transfer efficiency. This means the directed electron transfer is steadily enhanced with more POMs being loaded. Girardi et al. prepared [α-H2PW11O39{Rh(III)Cp*(OH2)}]3−, which has a similar effect on the improvement of electron transfer efficiency [140]. This POM organometallic derivative provides accessible ligand sites in the RhIII center. Previously Girardi et al. have tried to combine POMs with electrocatalysis of CO2RR and prepared (TOA)6[α-SiW11O39Co(_)] (_= vacancy in the Co coordination layer) [72]. This catalyst could reduce CO2 to CO and HCHO without the by-product H2. This is due to vacancies in the Co coordination layer and defects on the POMs. In the CO2RR process, the number and state of active electrons are noteworthy. Some catalyst materials could provide electron channels. This could make it easier to allow substances to approach and accelerate electron transfer in reactions [145]. For instance, Zha et al. constructed an electrocatalytic CO2 reduction system using Keggin-type POM [SiW9V3O40]7− with In [145]. At −0.71 V (vs. RHE), the acetate produces a Faradaic efficiency of 96.5% with selectivity close to 96%. In fact, during the reaction, the redox potential of V, which is the center of SiW9V3, is higher than In's. Therefore, it is likely that there is also an electron transfer between the In electrode and SiW9V3. This suggests that V also acted as a catalytically active center in CO2RR. The In0/In3+ ratio on the surface of indium decreased from 0.13 to 0.04 after electrolysis at −0.71 V for 1 h. This indicates that the surface of the indium electrode is oxidized while SiW9V3 catalyzes the reduction of CO2. This catalyst change lowers the overpotential, thereby increasing the Faradaic efficiency and facilitating the reduction of CO2 to acetic acid (C2H3O2 −) and formic acid (HCOO−) [146]. Similarly, Bi-PMo nanosheets prepared by Guo et al. exhibited higher reduction current at the same potential compared to pure Bi nanocrystals [142]. The performance of the catalysts was tested at a potential of −0.86 V using 0.5 M NaHCO3 as a solvent. The FEHCOOH was 93%±2% and the partial current density of HCOOH was as high as 30 mA cm−2. The authors attributed the enhanced CO2 reducing activity to the higher ECSA of Bi-PMo nanosheets, which allowed the electrode to react over a wider range of potentials. Moreover, Ag electrodeposited Keggin-type polymetallic oxides [PMo12O40]3(PMo) demonstrated higher catalytic activity compared to plain Ag electrodes [139]. The Ag-PMo nanomaterial-modified electrode achieved FECO of 90% during CO2RR in dimethylformamide (DMF) in the potential range used. The Tafel slope of 60 mV dec−1 suggests that rapid formation of CO 2 Â·- . These results indicate that the reaction proceeds faster and more efficiently at the Ag-PMo modified electrode due to the reduced overpotential of the strong interaction between PMo and CO 2 Â·- . 3.2.2 Practical optimization Incorporating POMs as electrolytes in the CO2RR process has been shown to significantly decrease overpotential, thus improving the efficiency of the reaction. Li et al. [147] and Zha et al. [145] demonstrated the benefits of using POMs as electrolytes without incorporating them into electrode preparation. Li et al. used SiW11Mn and showed a decrease in the experimental overpotential. The material overcomes the low selectivity limitation of In for C2 products. At a potential of −0.8 V vs. Ag/AgCl (-0.35 vs. RHE), the products were acetic and formic acids with Faradaic efficiencies of 72.1% and 6.1%, respectively. Zha et al. used the SiW9V3 material and observed an increase in the FE (between 23.7% and 96.5%) of acetic acid during CO2 conversion. However, their experiments demonstrated that when the electrolyte did not contain SiW9V3, acetic acid was no longer present in the product. This proves that POMs still affect the selectivity of CO2RR even as an electrolyte. Sun et al. conducted further research, adding SVW11 to the electrolyte [148]. As the electrolysis time increased, the atomic ratio of W and V content decreased, and the POMs' structure became isomeric. This change effectively reduced the reaction's overpotential and improved the product's selectivity (Fig. 12 a). Combining the results of XPS and Raman spectroscopy tests, the researchers concluded that the chemical valence state of V in SVW11 changed from +5 to +4 after the reaction (Fig. 12b and c). CO2RR was involved in this valence transition process, providing a pathway for electron transfer. Furthermore, Sun et al. found a synergistic effect between In and (n-Bu4N)3SVMo11O40 as an electrolyte for CO2 reduction [149]. They detected the intermediates involved in the CO2RR process by in-situ FTIR spectroscopy during the reaction (Fig. 13 a–c). The results showed that the formation time of *HCOO− was shorter than that of *CO. This suggests that the carbon atoms in CO2 first hydrogenate to form *HCOO−, then the oxygen atoms protonate to form *CO. From the in-situ results of the control experiments, it could be found that indium could help to form the *CHO and *HCOO intermediates to obtain the C1 product further, and SVMo11 facilitates the CC coupling (*COCO). Therefore, it could deduce that the catalyst and SVMo11 possess the synergistic effect of promoting the CC coupling of *COCHO. POMs accelerated the hydrogenation and protonation of CO2 on the In surface, and the electrons generated by the oxygen vacancy on In migrated to VMo11O40 3−, converting Mo6+ to Mo4+. This explains the catalytic effect of SVW11 on acetic acid production observed in previous experiments [120,150]. The ratio of In0:In3+ decreased from 1.80 in 1 h to 0.62 in 3 h, indicating that In0 was converted to In3+ via CO2RR with increasing electrolysis time (Fig. 13d). They concluded that the electron transfer from In2O3 to SVMoVI11O40 3− is thermodynamically favorable to produce. This is because the redox potential of SVMo11 is more positive than that of In2O3. The cations in (n-Bu4N)3SVMo11O40 may play a role similar to that of an ionic liquid for CO2RR. These findings highlight the importance of exploring alternative applications of materials in CO2RR electrocatalyst synthesis. POMs dispersed in a solution as an electrolyte makes their advantage in storing and transporting electrons [145]. This insight could inspire researchers not to limit materials to existing ways of using them. It may serve as an inspiration for the development of raw materials for the synthesis of CO2RR electrocatalysts. The influence of different POM species and traits on CO2RR reactions is crucial in optimizing the electrochemical reduction process. Thus, selecting the appropriate POM species and their combinations with metals is vital for achieving optimal results in CO2RR processes. Du et al. investigated the modulation of electron transfer by different POMs in a series of novel POM carbonylmanganese (POM-MnL) complexes [136]. They found that using different POM species, such as H3PMo12O40, could affect the simultaneous CO2RR and HER processes. SiW12-MnL/KB could reach FECO up to 95% at −0.72 V (vs. RHE). The difficulty in electron transport from PMo12 to the MnL core facilitated the generation of H2, which is detrimental to CO2RR. They also found that SiW12-MnL/KB has good CO2RR stability. The researchers observed the excellent stability of SiW12-MnL/KB from IR spectra after 12 h of electrolysis further confirmed (Fig. 14 a). They emphasize the importance of selecting suitable POM species for efficient CO2RR reactions. Yang et al. developed a new material preparation method by infiltrating PMo12 as an interlayer into two Zn-CoTAPc (zinc−cobalt(tetraamino)-phthalocyanine) mesh layers to create bilayer intercalated nanosheets [134] (Fig. 14b). At a potential of −0.7 V (vs. RHE), this material has a maximum FECO of 96.1%. They also explored using similar or smaller-sized POMs instead of PMo12 to synthesize the material. The authors found that the resulting material forms were irregular and exhibited different morphologies, with no formation of nanosheets. This highlights that the choice of POM species and sizes plays a crucial role in determining the morphology and performance of synthesized materials. Wang et al. [126] and Zhao et al. [63] demonstrated that pairing POMs with specific metals could improve catalytic performance in CO2RR. Wang et al. prepared five materials using different POMs and metals, among which only [NiII4(dm4bt)8(GeW12O40)2(H2O)2]·4H2O exhibited better catalytic performance for CO2RR (dm4bt = 2,2′-dimethyl-4,4′bithiazole), reaching an FECO of 86.3% at −0.9 V (vs. RHE). Zhao et al., through DFT calculations, identified Sc, Cr, Mn, Ti, and V as candidate metals for the TM site of TM@Na4SiMo12. They found that V@Na4SiMo12 has an enormous V–O bonding strength, indicating a smaller ΔG of CO2 to HCOO* and making it a suitable candidate. Ti@SiMo12 was found to be suitable for electron storage in CO2RR. At the same time, Cr@Na4SiMo12 exhibited a shallow limiting potential (U L) of CO2RR at only 0.23 V. High selectivity and effective catalytic activity were demonstrated by Mn-@Na4SiMo12 for HCOOH in CO2RR. Overall, excellent CO2RR catalysts should have good electron transfer efficiency. Meanwhile, different metal sites could realize different catalytic effects. However, we face the limitation of material selection in practical applications. Therefore, it is significant to introduce mathematical simulation into catalyst screening to provide a reference for selecting feedstock and reducing the cost of catalyst development. Mathematical simulations, such as DFT calculations, provide valuable insights into the electronic structure, properties, behavior, reaction mechanisms, and kinetics of materials. Wasted resources could be reduced by comparing simulation results with direct experimental results. Conducting experiments based on simulations reduces the time and resources spent on trial-and-error experiments. 3.3 Layered hydroxides Layered hydroxides are a unique category of 2D anionic clay materials belonging to the broader class of inorganic functional materials. Due to their laminar structure, they could modify interlayer interactions, which allows for tuning their properties for various applications, including biology, medicine, electrochemical energy storage and conversion, electrocatalysis, and anionic conduction [151,152]. Layered double hydroxide (LDH) is a subclass of layered hydroxides containing numerous metal cations. The physicochemical properties of LDHs could be adjusted by altering the molar ratio between metal ions or changing the interlayer anions, enabling researchers to design materials with tailored properties for specific applications [152]. The main plate of layered hydroxides could be utilized as a container to improve properties by inserting other molecules or even act as a “molecular switch” [153–155]. In electrochemistry, layered hydroxides and LDHs, in particular, have been investigated for their potential as electrocatalysts and anionic conductors [156–158]. The tunability of LDHs makes them promising candidates for developing electrocatalysts with enhanced activity and selectivity, as shown in Table 4 . Their overlapping layers provide suitable accommodation for CO2 and intermediates involved in the reaction. In this respect, they are similar to porous metal oxides (although in this context they're not all porous materials). It has been suggested that nanoconfinement between two parallel planes restricts the movement of species to the space between the planes. However, it is freer compared to pores and less accessible compared to nanoconfinement [36]. At the same time, most of them possessed considerable specific surface area after the BET test. Although they are not formal porous metal oxides, they are suitable for comparison materials for porous metal oxide catalysts. There are thus many opportunities for researchers to gain inspiration from them. Due to the frequent presence of multiple components, positive promotion of CO2RR formed between components is often present in LDH-type catalysts. First, synergistic effects between metals are relatively common. Li et al. constructed a multiphase-structured catalyst named CuO/In(OH)3-CNT (carbon nanotube) [169]. This catalyst had an FECO of 89% at −1.0 V (vs. RHE) (Fig. 15 a). CuO was reduced to Cu, and the synergistic interaction between Cu and In(OH)3 contributed to the excellent catalytic performance. Similarly, Yang et al. tested the catalyst CoFe-LDH/SP, which possesses a larger CO2 adsorption capacity and adsorption selectivity compared to the standard particulate sample [164] (Fig. 15b). It had a low interfacial charge transfer resistance. Upon testing, the researchers found that the used samples' SEM images and XPS spectra showed minimal changes. They calculated the differential charge density of CoOFe bonds in CoFe-LDH/HP by DFT (Fig. 15c). The results show that more charges could be accumulated around the CoOFe bond, and there is an intense electron exchange between *COOH and CoOFe. This suggests that CoFe-LDH/HP facilitates the stabilization of *COOH intermediates. The idea of synergistic effect is also supported by Ma et al. [165] They prepared Cd-MgAl-LDHs@RGO with FECO reach to 91.5% at −1.1 V (vs. RHE). They attributed the excellent electrocatalytic performance of the catalysts to the partial substitution of Mg by Cd during the synthesis process, which improves the synergistic effect and promotes electron transfer. Li et al. reported the application of LDHs as CO2RR electrocatalysts, demonstrating their potential in this field [162]. N-doped NiZnAl calcined layered double hydroxide on graphene (N-NiZnAl CLDH/RGO) achieved up to an FECO up to 92% and a current density of 9.4 mA cm−2 of CO at −0.83 V (vs. RHE). NiO and ZnO showed synergistic effects, with the most pronounced effect when Ni:Zn was 1:1. In CO2 electroreduction, elemental Zn was maintained in the ZnO state, and a small amount of NiO was reduced to Ni (Fig. 15d and e). However, even if the synergistic effect exists, it also requires precise control of the active site [166]. Iwase et al. adjusted the size of the LDH particles by controlling the pH and temperature (Fig. 16 a). In most catalyst materials, metal nanoparticles on the substrate need to be dispersed and fully exposed. For example, Fu et al. exfoliated NiFe-LDH using a solid-phase method to obtain NiFe-CN monolayer catalysts with a fine filament and porous structure [159] (Fig. 16b). With the gradual increase of metal doping, the metal started to aggregate to form alloy particles that covered the active sites, reducing the selectivity and reaction rate of CO (Fig. 16c and d). Chen et al. prepared CNT@NiFe-LDH NS catalysts based on solid-phase exfoliation and electrostatic self-assembly [160]. Carbon nanotubes could dispersively load metal nanoparticles to expose their active sites completely. The CO2RR activity of the catalysts will increase and then decrease with increasing NiFe ratio in CNT-N-NiFe for reasons similar to those derived by Fu et al. Similar to porous metal oxides and POMs, sometimes LDHs require other materials to reinforce them. For example, C-containing materials could enhance the material's conductivity. Ko et al. synthesized a NiFe LDH-CNT-Co3O4/NC electrocatalyst [161]. The catalyst combines hydrophilic Ni-Fe LDH with a highly mesoporous carbon matrix, creating favorable ionic pathways for rapid diffusion and efficient mass transfer (Fig. 17 a). The combination with CNTs further enhanced the conductivity during the redox process, in which Ni, Fe, Co3O4, and N-doped bonds played a major role in the catalytic process. For example, Malik et al. prepared a CoCrLDH_O-CNT catalyst for OER, which exhibited good OER activity due to the joint interaction between LDH and CNTs [170]. Ma et al. also agreed that incorporating RGO improved the electrical conductivity of the materials [165]. In addition to the conductivity enhancement, the C-containing materials could enhance the catalytic ability and lifetime of LDHs catalysts. Altaf et al. used Cu-Cu2O nanocomposites, highly enriched with subsurface oxygen from CO2RR [167]. The small nanoparticles in the composite formed clusters stacked on each other in a layered structure (Fig. 17b and c). Their further studies on the Cu-containing composites showed that the incorporation of reduced graphene oxide greatly improved the C2H4 selectivity of the catalyst, achieving FE up to 54% and high current density [73]. The ECSA of ER-Cu5-LDH/rGO is higher than that of Cu2O/rGO, indicating better dispersion of Cu in the material. However, the connection between LDHs and additional materials is also noteworthy. For example, Liu et al. prepared Ni-AlO(OH)3@RGO using RGO as a carrier for in-situ growth of NiAlO(OH)3 (nickel-doped layered boehmite) [156]. This catalyst could reach a FECO up to 92.2% at −0.9 V (vs. RHE). Although having a better catalytic effect, the catalysts could only operate stably at this potential for 3 h. The FECO decreased from 92.2% to 65%. There are several reasons for the decay of FECO during the reaction: (1) the catalyst is coated on the carbon paper electrode with a binder that prevents the two from adequately combining and catalyzing the reaction; and (2) as the reaction proceeds, a large number of bubbles generated on the surface of the electrode take away or displace the catalyst coated on the carbon paper electrode. The effective catalyst is reduced, which leads to HER gradually becoming the main reaction. Layered hydroxides' overlapping layers, nanoconfinement, and resemblance to porous metal oxides make them a relevant topic in the context of CO2 reduction [152]. In CO2RR, synergistic effects between metals, size control, and careful metal doping are crucial aspects in their application. Similar to porous metal oxides, sometimes LDHs require other materials to reinforce them, enhancing conductivity and catalytic ability [170]. However, the connection between LDHs and additional materials and the stability during the reaction must be carefully managed. The nuanced relationship between layered structure and porosity may vary depending on specific design and application. Their structure, synergies, and integration with other materials could lead to innovative solutions in areas such as electrocatalysis. 3.4 Zeolite-like materials Zeolite, a porous silica-aluminate material, boasts high stability and porosity, making it an excellent choice for CO2 capture due to its gas adsorption and channel transfer capabilities [171–173]. These unique properties have attracted significant research interest in developing zeolite-based materials for various applications. However, zeolite and its derivatives are more commonly used in gas adsorption and separation [174–177], thermal catalysis [178–180], and photocatalysis [181–184] rather than in electrocatalytic CO2RR. This is primarily due to some material limitations, such as their insulating properties, which hinder their direct use as catalysts for CO2RR [185–187]. Zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs), a subclass of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), have demonstrated remarkable chemical and thermal stability, offering the potential for efficient catalytic and separation engineering. In these substances, imidazole salt ligands are spatially arranged with metal ions, forming structures similar to those in zeolite structures with cavities and nanoscale channels [171–173]. The application of zeolite and zeolite-like materials (including their derivatives and ZIFs) for CO2RR is illustrated by many references and will not be discussed in detail in this review [188–191]. Many zeolite derivatives, such as zeolite template carbon (ZTC), are based on carbon as an essential component. Papanikolaou et al. prepared a high-conductivity material based on β-zeolite, exhibiting template zeolite tissue properties and a graphene-like structure [192]. Moreover, it has capable of reducing CO2 to HCOOH. The material's microporous nature, combined with the remarkable conductivity of graphene, results in a high specific surface area. The surface oxygen functional groups of ZTC enhance the electrocatalyst's wettability, facilitating the diffusion of hydrated CO2 to the active site [193,194]. To overcome zeolite's material limitations, researchers have started exploring the development of hybrid catalyst systems incorporating zeolite structures with more catalytically active materials [195–199]. These hybrid systems aim to leverage zeolite structures' porosity, stability, and high surface area while overcoming their inherent limitations. Recent material synthesis and engineering advancements have opened new avenues for developing zeolite-based catalysts with enhanced performance. Advanced techniques such as atomic layer deposition, sol–gel synthesis, and electrospinning could be used to create catalysts with optimized pore size, surface area, and chemical composition to tailor zeolite materials' properties further. Furthermore, computational methods like DFT could help researchers better understand the structure–property relationships of zeolite materials, guiding the design of more effective catalysts for CO2RR applications. 3.5 Application extension: Binding to solid oxide electrolytic cell (SOEC) However, electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction using electricity alone has disadvantages, such as low efficiency and insufficient energy utilization. Researchers are exploring ways to combine electricity with heat, light, and biological CO2 reduction methods to achieve better results. Electrothermal catalysis, particularly SOEC, is a promising direction for enhancing CO2RR performance. Traditional SOECs used nickel-based ceramic electrodes as the primary fuel electrode (cathode), which were prone to oxidation [200]. To address this issue, researchers have developed alternative electrode materials and structures. For example, Chen et al. introduced NiCeO y nanoparticles onto porous Ni/YSZ electrodes, resulting in even distribution of the nanoparticles and improved I-V performance [201] (Fig. 18 a). Researchers have also explored replacing nickel in SOEC electrodes with other metals, although these alternatives often face limitations such as high costs or reduced reactivity [202]. Zhang et al. prepared a cathode using a porous 430 stainless steel skeleton as a carrier [203]. They coated the surface with nano-sized Sm0.2Ce0.8O2- δ (SDC) particles, demonstrating high reaction efficiency and test stability (Fig. 18b and c). Perovskite oxide-based electrodes have been proposed as an alternative, with Sr2Fe1.5Mo0.5O6- δ (SFM) identified as a potential SOEC electrode material. However, SFM exhibits insufficient activity for CO2RR. Lv et al. infiltrated Gd0.2Ce0.8O1.9 (GDC) nanoparticles into SFM to prepare a GDC-SFM composite electrode with lower polarization resistance, increased surface active sites, and a higher density of three-phase boundaries (TPBs) [204] (Fig. 19 a and b). Zhang et al. replaced GDC with alkaline earth metal compounds to infiltrate SFM [205]. They prepared a composite heterostructure material, CaCO3-SFM (Fig. 19c), demonstrating comparable performance to the GDC-SFM composite electrode. Using alkaline earth metal compounds contributes to the increased stability of the material. Despite these advancements, SOECs' high reaction temperature (typically above 700 °C) limits the applicability of many materials that may carbonize above 300 °C and lose their original functionality. Researchers could explore composite materials that combine the strengths of various materials and control the reaction temperature, ideally around 100 °C. By introducing pressure, it may be possible to achieve high-efficiency CO2RR with composite catalysis at specific voltages [206]. 4 Summary and outlook The urgency of reducing fossil fuel reliance has led researchers to explore efficient electrochemical CO2RR projects. Due to its simplicity and lower cost compared to thermochemistry and photochemistry, we focus on CO2RR. This paper highlights several porous metal oxide materials in CO2RR electrocatalysis, summarizing their advantages, characteristics and expanding application directions. In this paper, we can find that the catalyst has undergone many changes during the reaction. Phase transitions and crystal structure changes are critical factors that contribute to the complexity and efficiency of catalysts in CO2RR. The transformation is not just a mere morphological alteration but reveals a dynamic process involving different metallic components. It plays a vital role in facilitating electron transfer, leading to insights into the redox behavior of catalysts and how electronic structure modification and vacancy migration occur. In terms of shape change, the transition often occurs during the catalytic reaction. This affects the reduction effect and current density behavior. The specific surface area change, on the other hand, relates to the availability of active sites on the catalyst surface. This attribute is essential for enhancing reactivity by providing more accessible reaction sites for CO2 and other reactants. Through the analysis of both in-situ and ex-situ characterizations like Raman spectroscopy, XRD, FESEM, and XPS, we get a deeper understanding of the redox behavior of catalysts, electronic structure modification, and vacancy migration [149]. As a result, they provide a comprehensive view of how different metallic components, morphological changes, and surface areas affect efficiency, stability, and selectivity in CO2RR. Hence, the phase transition and crystal structure changes are not isolated phenomena, which could be interconnected with other aspects of catalyst evolution, such as valence state and specific surface area changes. The findings emphasize the crucial roles of different metal oxides in achieving effective, efficient, and stable CO2 reduction. These insights significantly contribute to understanding catalyst performance in CO2RR, paving the way for further research and applications in this vital field. At the same time, the nanoconfinement in metal oxide catalysts is deeply explored. It originated in the confined pore canals effect in microporous molecular sieves [207,208]. The confined pore canals effect of catalysts affects diffusion, adsorption, and catalytic properties. They allow the catalytic reaction to proceed more smoothly: properly sized pores accelerate diffusion when molecules move in and out of the pores, and increased adsorption capacity promotes the formation of reaction intermediates and products. Similarly, the influence of nanoconfinement on electrocatalysis is summarized by Wordsworth et al. recently [36]. The confined environment may lead to a change in electronic states, an increase in the local concentration of reactants, and the generation of unique reaction intermediates. All of these contribute to the observed enhanced reactivity. In the context of CO2RR, nanoconfinement has been shown to enhance selectivity and efficiency. Additionally, the interaction between the porous structure and the confined reactants could be finely tuned through chemical modification, doping, or integration with other functional materials. These modifications could further enhance the selectivity, stability, and scalability of the catalysts [25]. Integration of computational and simulation with experimental studies is providing deeper insights into the nanoconfinement effects, guiding the rational design of more effective catalysts. Suitable materials for CO2RR share certain similarities: low overpotential, good conductivity, high catalytic efficiency, rapid mass transfer, long service life, and cost-effectiveness. However, future trends should focus on several key aspects to bring the utility of CO2RR metal oxide electrodes to a higher level. 1. Catalyst Activity Enhancement. Researchers are looking into manipulating the electrode surface's redox state or structure, which in turn helps control the nature and distribution of active sites. By tuning these crystal defects, additional reaction sites can be offered. There's also a need to explore the use of composite catalysts, which could bring synergistic effects into play. All these efforts aim to improve the single conversion efficiency of CO2 while minimizing byproduct formation. 2. Catalyst Stability. High-quality metal oxides are preferable for electrode preparation, and multi-layer structures can provide additional stability. It is crucial to select appropriate potentials to avoid unnecessary catalyst degradation. Continuous monitoring for any changes within the catalyst is also important. 3. Reaction Mechanism Understanding. A deeper insight into the reaction mechanisms of metal oxides in CO2RR is crucial Combining theoretical models with experimental data enables a deeper understanding of the reaction mechanisms. This comprehensive approach could significantly reduce both resource consumption and the experimental burden, thereby enhancing the exploration efficiency of new electrode materials. 4. Scalability. Advanced fabrication techniques, like 3D printing and nanostructuring, offer precise control over electrode geometry and surface area. Integration with renewable energy sources and real-time monitoring through sensors make the process more sustainable. Integration with other fields will also expand its applications. In conclusion, the development and application of porous metal oxide materials in CO2RR hold great promise for addressing the urgent need to reduce fossil fuel reliance and mitigate climate change impacts. By focusing on innovative material design, hybrid systems, advanced characterization techniques, renewable energy integration, and scaling strategies, researchers could pave the way for a more sustainable, low-carbon future. Phys. Lett. 137 (1987) 336-340. Ziqi Zhang received her Bachelor of Engineering degree from Tiangong University, China in 2021. She is currently pursuing her M.S. degree in the School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tiangong University, China. Her research interests include the synthesis of bipolar membrane and nano-metal oxide, and their application in electrocatalytic reduction of CO2. Jinyun Xu received his Ph.D. from Tiangong University, China in 2010. After four years of postdoctoral research in the SINOPECLuoyang, his main research interest is the synthesis of metal oxides and electrochemical reduction of carbon dioxides. Yu Zhang received her Bachelor of Engineering degree from Binzhou University, China in 2021. She is currently studying for a master's degree in the School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tiangong University, China. Her research interests include mechanical ball grinding into oxide ceramicsand preparation of hydrolyzed ionization bipolar membranes. Liping Zhao received her Bachelor of Engineering degree from Shangqiu Normal College, China in 2021. She is now a master's student in the School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tiangong University, China. Her research interests include synthesis of acid - excited geopolymers and preparation of non - sintering ceramics. Ming Li received his Bachelor of Engineering degree from Binzhou University, China in 2021. He is currently studying for a master's degree in the School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tiangong University, China. His research interests include application of porous material modified functional electrode in environmental electrocatalytic organic wastewater treatment. Guoqiang Zhong received his Bachelor of Engineering degree in engineering from the College of Technology of Hebei University of Science and Technology, China in 2020 and his M.S. degree from Tiangong University, China in 2023. His research interests include the preparation of nanoporous metal oxides and their applications in the electrochemical reduction of CO2. Di Zhao received her Bachelor of Engineering degree from Binzhou University, China in 2020. She is currently pursuing her M.S. degree in the School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tiangong University, China. Her research interests include the controllable synthesis of porous inorganic catalysts of bipolar membrane interfacial layer and their applications in sustainable chemical and electrochemical processes. Minjing Li received her Bachelor of Engineering degree from Nanjing Tech University, China in 2020. She is currently studying for a Master's degree in the School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Tiangong University, China. Her research interests include alkali-excited geopolymers and their biomass pigment separation properties. Xudong Hu received his Ph.D. degree in School of Materials Science and Engineering, Tianjin University, China. He currently does his postdoctoral research in Professor Galen D. Stucky’s research group at the University of California, Santa Barbara. His research focuses on synthesis of high-performance anode materials for lithium-ion batteries and sodium-ion batteries. Wenju Zhu received his Ph.D. from Nankai University, China in 2013. After two years of postdoctoral research work in the School of Chemistry at Tsinghua University. In 2015, he joined the School of Chemical Engineering and Technology at Tiangong University. In 2019, he went to the University of California, Davis (UCD) as a visiting scholar. In 2020, he was promoted to associate professor. His research field is organic synthetic chemistry, especially the total synthesis of complex organic compounds and natural products. In recent years, his achievements lie in the development of a series of bio-based organic-inorganic hybrid flame retardants, and in cellulose, polyester, polyurethane, epoxy resin and other flame retardant aspects of the pioneering research. Chunming Zheng received the B.S., M.S. and Ph.D. degree from Nankai University, China in 2002, 2006 and 2010. He is now a professor of the School of Chemical Engineering and Technology at Tiangong University, China. His research interests include the controllable synthesis of nanoporous metal oxides and their applications in sustainable chemical and electrochemical processes. Xiaohong Sun is a professor in School of Materials Science and Engineering at Tianjin University in China. She received her B.S. and Ph.D. degree in 2005 and 2010 from Nankai University in China. Her research interests include the structure and morphology design, synthesis and characteristics of nanoscale and porous materials and their applications in electrochemical and energy storage.

coredata.dc:description: The global energy-related CO2 emissions have rapidly increased as the world economy heavily relied on fossil fuels. This paper explores the pressing challenge of CO2 emissions and highlights the role of porous metal oxide materials in the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 (CO2RR). The focus is on the development of robust and selective catalysts, particularly metal and metal-oxide-based materials. Porous metal oxides offer high surface area, enhancing the accessibility to active sites and improving reaction kinetics. The tunability of these materials allows for tailored catalytic behavior, targeting optimized reaction mechanisms for CO2RR. The work also discusses the various synthesis strategies and identifies key structural and compositional features, addressing challenges like high overpotential, poor selectivity, and low stability. Based on these insights, we suggest avenues for future research on porous metal oxide materials for electrochemical CO2 reduction.
